factors.title: Fragmented Land Administration
factors.description: Nigeria operates multiple land registration systems across different states, creating inconsistencies and confusion.

factors.title: Land Use Act Complications
factors.description: The 1978 Land Use Act vests all land in state governments, meaning individuals can only obtain rights of occupancy rather than absolute ownership.

factors.title: Certificate of Occupancy (C of O) Challenges
factors.description: Many properties lack proper C of O documentation, the primary evidence of legal right to land use.

factors.title: Family Land Disputes
factors.description: Land often belongs to extended families, leading to multiple claimants challenging sales made by individual family members.

factors.title: Fraudulent Titles
factors.description: Counterfeit land documents are common, particularly in high-demand areas.

factors.title: Incomplete Documentation
factors.description: Many properties have missing or incomplete documentation chains.

factors.title: Multiple Sales
factors.description: The same property may be sold to multiple buyers due to poor record-keeping.

factors.title: Gazumping
factors.description: Sellers may back out of agreements after accepting initial payments to pursue higher offers.

factors.title: Slow Judicial Process
factors.description: Property litigation can last 5-15 years in Nigerian courts.

factors.title: Inconsistent Enforcement
factors.description: Application of property laws varies widely between jurisdictions.

factors.title: Zoning Violations
factors.description: Properties may be built in violation of zoning regulations, risking future demolition.

factors.title: Price Bubbles
factors.description: Urban centers like Lagos and Abuja experience periodic property bubbles.

factors.title: Regional Disparities
factors.description: Property values can vary dramatically between and within cities.

factors.title: Illiquid Assets
factors.description: Reselling property can be difficult, especially in economic downturns.

factors.title: Naira Fluctuations
factors.description: The Nigerian currency's volatility affects real property values.

factors.title: Inflation Impact
factors.description: High inflation rates (averaging 15-18% in recent years) erode real property returns.

factors.title: Remittance Challenges
factors.description: International money transfer restrictions and costs impact investment capabilities.

factors.title: Registration Fees
factors.description: Property registration can cost 8-15% of the property value.

factors.title: Development Levies
factors.description: Local government and community development charges are often undisclosed before purchase.

factors.title: "Settlement" Payments
factors.description: Informal payments to community stakeholders may be expected.

factors.title: Infrastructure Costs
factors.description: Buyers often must self-fund basic infrastructure like roads, water, and electricity.

factors.title: Property Supervision
factors.description: Difficulty in overseeing construction or maintenance from abroad.

factors.title: Communication Barriers
factors.description: Time zone differences and unreliable communication infrastructure.

factors.title: Dependency on Representatives
factors.description: Reliance on potentially untrustworthy proxies for decision-making.

factors.title: Build Quality Concerns
factors.description: Substandard materials and workmanship are common.

factors.title: Project Delays
factors.description: Construction timelines frequently extend 2-3 times beyond estimates.

factors.title: Contractor Reliability
factors.description: Abandonment of projects after receiving advance payments.

factors.title: Power Supply
factors.description: Unreliable electricity necessitates expensive generator systems.

factors.title: Water Access
factors.description: Many properties require private boreholes or water delivery systems.

factors.title: Road Accessibility
factors.description: Properties may become inaccessible during rainy seasons due to poor roads.

factors.title: Security Concerns
factors.description: Additional investments in security systems and personnel may be necessary.

factors.title: Changing Regulations
factors.description: Frequent policy changes affect property rights and taxation.

factors.title: Government Appropriation
factors.description: Risk of land reclamation for "public purpose" with inadequate compensation.

factors.title: Political Influence
factors.description: Property rights enforcement often depends on political connections.

factors.title: Opaque Pricing
factors.description: Lack of transparent pricing mechanisms creates valuation difficulties.

factors.title: Limited Market Data
factors.description: Absence of reliable property indices or historical sales data.

factors.title: Misinformation
factors.description: Deliberate misrepresentation of property potential by interested parties.

factors.title: Civil Unrest
factors.description: Communal conflicts can devalue property or render it unusable.

factors.title: Terrorism Impact
factors.description: Northern regions face Boko Haram threats affecting property markets.

factors.title: Urban Crime
factors.description: High-crime areas face property devaluation and rental challenges.
